abstract.p: Pres Clinton signs bill making electronic signatures legal (S)

block.p: President Clinton inserted a signature card into a computer today to affirm his support of legislation giving legal weight to electronic signatures.

Congress endorsed the e-signature legislation this year after months of back-and-forth with the White House. The law, intended to foster business transactions over the Internet, allows electronic contracts to be sealed online.
President Clinton inserted a signature card into a computer today to affirm his support of legislation giving legal weight to electronic signatures.

Congress endorsed the e-signature legislation this year after months of back-and-forth with the White House. The law, intended to foster business transactions over the Internet, allows electronic contracts to be sealed online.

Officially, Mr. Clinton signed the bill into law the traditional way, with a felt-tip pen. But to show what the legislation may mean in the future, Mr. Clinton also slipped the signature card through a scanner, typed in a not-so-secret password -- ''Buddy,'' for his Labrador retriever -- and marveled as a replica of his signature appeared on the screen.
By giving electronic signatures legal standing, the new law will enable consumers to sign contracts for bank loans, new cars and other business deals from home.
The law's backers say businesses will save billions of dollars a year.
